Even though there are some widely used biomarkers to monitor the renal function in chronic diseases such as the levels of urea, creatinine, cystatin C, inulin, iothalamate and chromium-EDTA
45 , 46 , they are not helpful in yellow fever, because of the appalling disease severity and progression. According to the WHO
33 , if there is hepato-renal failure, up to 50% of the patients will die within 7 to 10 days, and those who do not die, may experience a long period of recovery from liver and kidney damages
15 . Consequently, these data highlights the importance of more studies on the kidney involvement in YF disease, because they are very important organs that are indirect targets of the disease, with severe consequences.
